summary: Realizing the stakes are no longer just for survival, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) teams up with her closest friends, including Peeta (Josh Hutcherson), Gale (Liam Hemsworth) and Finnick for the ultimate mission. Together, they leave District 13 to liberate the citizens of war-torn Panem and assassinate President Snow, who's obsessed with destroying Katniss. What lies ahead are mortal traps, dangerous enemies and moral choices that will ultimately determine the future of millions.

reviews.content: This is a perfect trilogy in my eyes & a satisfying way to end things off. A great ending to a great story & overall I can't wait for the prequel later this year. 10/10.
Great movie! The movie was not rushed and properly aligned with the first movie.
I promised my family I would give this movie a five-star review if Katniss killed Coin instead of Snow. All in all, not a spectacular movie but definitely worth watching.

Mockingjay Part 2 is a worthy conclusion to the series. This closing film does a solid job of providing good balance in the action and diplomacy. The conclusion had a satisfying end and it did not leave viewers handing or grasping for answers.

They literally killed the best character in the entire franchise and I will never support any hunger games movie in the future unless the story line is about reviving the christ amongst humans (finnick)

Una película aceptable, pero un final decepcionante para la saga. La película empieza bien y ofrece buena acción y drama, pero a medida que avanza, toda expectativa comienza a descender. En realidad este no es el final épico que la saga podría haber tenido y la muerte de la hermanita de Katniss fue algo injusto al final. Las actuaciones, la acción, la banda sonora y la producción son destacables. Jennifer Lawrence aún sigue siendo lo mejor de la saga y es una pena que esta película como capítulo final deja mucho que desear. Un final bastante suave y nada épico para una saga que empezó muy bien en sus inicios con las primeras dos entregas. Mi calificación final para esta película es un 7/10.
This movie was awful. I loved the first three, and then I wanted this movie to end as soon as it started. This movie SUCKS.

I'm about an hour and a three minutes into this one , I like it. It occurs to me that I haven't mentioned Donald Sutherland yet , I've loved him since MASH , and he's perfect here . It's Steven Tucci ( who I've also really loved ) who was great in all of them , but , is especially good here.
pretty much the same as part 1 for me, and the ending is not as satisfactory as I'd like.
85/100 - great series. my first introduction to jennifer lawrence. she played her part well and the movies are well worth watching.
Unwatchable totaly weak, stupid shite; E x 6
Una saga de películas que tenia todo para ser de mis favoritas en toda la vida pero ambas partes de mockingjay la tiraron tan abajo que solo se me ocurre una palabra: desilusión. Es un final y basta.
Good conclusion and well don’t by the cast. Not as good as the rest

Excessively sad in nature, Mockingjay Part 2 brings the Hunger Games franchise to a satisfying, emotionally riveting and action-packed conclusion, that despite slow pace during the first act and some hasty moments, features mesmorizing performances from its phenomenal cast, terrific direction from Francis Lawrence and a solidly written screenplay that honors the entire franchise and brings it to its earned conclusion. Fantastic score as well.
What a bad way to end a trilogy 😪

This movie has the proper story arc that the prior film lacked, but somehow lost the production quality of the first three films. What I mean by this is that the beginning of the film drags, it feels like they just wanted to get to the awesome traps and fight scenes. It was still fun to watch though so I'd recommend it.

Strong ending of an immaculate franchise. 
Jennifer Lawrence brought Katniss' journey to a gracious end.
Ah yes another instance where the movie is so much better than the movies. Also Jennifer Lawrence seemed like she was phoning it in like every other role she does
Definitely a very satisfying ending to a great story. It puts things right at the end by showing how the good person is really bad.

This installment exposes the rudimentary, childlike writing style Suzanne used on this series more than any of the previous 3 movies. She inserted just enough political machinations and war maneuvering to mask the fact that any given citizen could deduce their way through the ones she thought of. The notion that they absolutely littered the entire city with death traps and thought not to put anything in the easily-accessible sewer system until after they'd went there is just completely unbelievable and neither side would ever have put themselves in position for the climax to happen the way it did; if detonating really was Coin's idea then Snow's decision to bring everyone to his mansion is among the dumbest choices in the history of war. They didn't play up Peeta's "real or not real" thing enough for her choosing him over the far superior Gale  to feel right. The sewer part of the journey was unnecessarily long and the zombies, while effectively suspenseful, felt contrived for the sole purpose of killing off some of the protagonists. Of all the young adult literature adaptations from the era this one has the worst finale of them all by quite a wide margin.
Amazing. Atemporal. Incredible.
Greatly but still poorly made I hate this film and love it at the same time
I didn't like it, maybe because I was expecting a lot more for it being the conclusion of the series.

I went to see this film for closure rather than to see another badly written, predictable storyline. I've never read the books, and I doubt I will if they're anything like the movie. The first film was at least entertaining (albeit I wasn't fond of the brutality towards children, which regrettably persisted throughout the series). Some of the supporting characters were more interesting to me than the two headliners. The second picture was adequate, and the third should have been the final instalment because nothing in Part 2 could not have been expected from Part 1 and so could not have been included. I agree with some of the criticism; I couldn't care less who Katniss choose.

An amazing finale, just as good as the first Hunger Games, a great wrap up too an amazing story that's told amazingly well. The performances are spot on and everything was executed correctly from script too screen. It's an overall great ending too the Hunger Games movies from start too finish. It's flawless and everything fits right in.
Loved the series very well done
My girlfriend at the time and I really liked it

All I can say is: annoying, I really wanted to enjoy the film and a lot of it was very promising but so many elements were just annoying, such as, we didn't even see them finally conquer, we were simply told by someone that they won! That was the main conclusion to the whole hunger games…and we didn't see it! Seriously

Not having read the book, I can't compare the movie(s) to the original text. However Mockingjay part 2 wraps up the story well in a surprising ending that defies typical Hollywood tropes. The cast are excellent and props to Jennifer Lawrence in the titular role. Much better movie and series than I expected.
Zdecydowanie najgorsza odsłona serii. Chcąc kontynuować wątki poprzedniczki oraz być zwieńczeniem całej serii robi to wszystko pobieżnie i nieudolnie niestety

When you watch all films from start to finish consecutively, you realise just how great the last two really are. They operate on a different level than the first two for lore reasons. If you get it, you get it. Respect to the director.
Being a technically clever movie, "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2" simply suffers from the fact that it is just plain boring.

Não tenho palavras para descrever o quão ruim é o filme, arrastado, entediante, chato, desperdiça personagens com grandes potências e tem um desfecho ridículo, eles tem muita sorte dos atores que estão no filme que dão uma salvada, mas é um completo desastre

The last two films were just an exploit, should have been one, but if you've seen the first two will likely buy two more tickets to see the ending. They weren't bad, but with half of the story omitted from the books, there was no reason to make this a two part finale.
This isn't as good as the rest of the series and it has a bunch of changes from the book.

I was a fan of the books and I read every one of them. But I was not that impressed with the movies, I guess because they were so PG-13. I believe that futuristic movies need to be a bit more violent to be realistic if they really want to portray and depict exactly what the books wanted.

The grand finale of the Hunger Games saga sees Jennifer Lawrence and her team of rebels on a mission to end the chaos and take down the president.  I probably should have rewatched part 1 before this one as I kind of forgot what had happened in the previous instalment.  While this boasts a fantastic cast and is shot stunningly, it was probably my least favourite of the series.

Ultimo capitolo in cui sicuramente gli effetti speciali sono migliorati notevolmente, e in cui tutti i personaggi trovano spazio.
Purtroppo ci sono degli aspetti che non sono sviluppati degnamente, troppi morti ravvicinate ed inutili visto l'andamento della guerra (perchè usare il sottosuolo quando comunque non si guadagna terreno)?
Gli ultimi minuti poi sono abbastanza un'agonia, con nessun personaggio che sembra trovare un posto nel nuovo mondo.
Comunque si conclude in maniera sufficiente un importante franchise che ha riscosso un notevole successo.

After three movies, you'd expect the end of the war to be more special, but it sadly ended with slow anticlimactic parachute bombs. Not to mention there were only about two or three scenes that felt really intense in over two hours. But like the book, my favorite part was the end (not because it was over). Everyone Katniss cared about was gone and you could really sympathies for her.

The series ends with a grand finale of events that you can't miss. With the obvious amazing talent on and off screen, the story wraps up nicely and takes major hits along the way and actually has several plot twists for the viewers that aren't familiar with the novel. This film series has truly shown others an example of how to do a film series adaptation of a novel justice.

I just came from seeing The Hunger Games: Mocking Jay Part 2! Based on the award winning book, the long awaited sequel marks the finale of the film series that made actress Jennifer Lawrence a star and inspired young girls the world over to rock the braided ponytail and take up archery classes. When we last left Katniss Everdeen and her friends, she was in the midst of planning an invasion of the Capitol city in District 1 to seize control of the country of Panam from the villainous President Snow who had just succeeded in brainwashing and turning the love of Katniss' life Peeta and turning into a slobbering lap dog of the capitol. Now, Ms. Everdeen and company soldier on towards The Capitol, destiny and a reckoning with President Snow.

I really have to commend this movie on its faithfulness to the book. Director Francis Lawrence really did a great job of turning the book into an action packed adventure. The movie was well shot and the supporting cast did a really good job too especially Jena Malone and Michelle Forbes. The only qualms I have with the movie come from it's dramatic moments between Peeta and Katniss which all come off as hokey and overly manufactured to seem more dramatic than they should be. At the same time, other moments, that actually were naturally dramatic and probably should have been focused on are played a lot dryer than they should have been. Ultimately, I can't fault the movie too much because in actuality, the book played things out in the same way, and what am I going to do about that? Complain that the movie is too much like the book?

On the whole, I liked a lot that this movie had to offer. The special effects and action sequences were very impressive and it was very loyal to the source material; so much so that the only things I didn't like about the movie were the same things I didn't like about the book. So if you liked the novels, I definitely recommend seeing the film but if you're just a movie watcher, you might be less satisfied. In the end The Mocking Jay Part 2 gets a 3.5...out of 5.
We came a long way to take an interesting premise down a long road that has been way-too-heavily traveled.
This one was probably my favorite of the Hunger Games films, but it still did not surpass any expectations. 8/10
i know a lot of people think these movies are amazing but they truly are just more bland, cgi action movies with ok writing a few good scenes at best.

I think that the movie was pretty good and they did a good job making it similar to the book. I didn't cry the whole movie up until the part where there was the little girl and her mom was dead and she was screaming "Mommy, Mommy!!" Omgsh I am crying right now. My only problem with it is the ending, I know they did it how it was in the book though I feel like it was unsatisfactory and her life seemed dull and boring.

The series ends with a grand finale of events that you can't miss. With the obvious amazing talent on and off screen, the story wraps up nicely and takes major hits along the way and actually has several plot twists for the viewers that aren't familiar with the novel. This film series has truly shown others an example of how to do a film series adaptation of a novel justice.

Mostly satisfying ending to the franchise with great acting, great emotional moments with Finnick and Prim's death as well as the ending, the visuals and sets are just as good as the other movies, the action scenes are pretty exciting and it has this massive scale to it and it stayed incredibly loyal to the book and stayed unpredictable and different from usual endings. There's some really memorable moments as well like Coin's death, the battle in the sewers and the ending scene. Also, I love how it wasn't just a predictable finale about the rebels marching into the capitol and killing Snow. It has deep themes about the futility of war and tryannical rulers emerging. the However, cutting the book into two parts really affected this movie. Mockingjay Part 1 did drag out a bit but it wasn't a big deal but considering this is a part 2 and the book is pretty short at 390 pages, it made the movie drag and have more build up and it's clear they were trying to stretch it to a 2 hour movie.  It also suffers from blindly following the book ironically. Mockingjay is easily my least favorite Hunger Games book (still good but not great) due to infuriating decisions in the story like knocking Katniss out when the rebels finally win as well as not really letting Katniss do much! It's still a good ending but it's no Deathly Hallows Part 2 or Return of the King. (B)

Excessively sad in nature, Mockingjay Part 2 brings the Hunger Games franchise to a satisfying, emotionally riveting and action-packed conclusion, that despite slow pace during the first act and some hasty moments, features mesmorizing performances from its phenomenal cast, terrific direction from Francis Lawrence and a solidly written screenplay that honors the entire franchise and brings it to its earned conclusion. Fantastic score as well.
this is easily the least fav Hunger Games film. I'm really annoyed they killed off finic and I didn't really like Peter turning into a rage Monster.
A satisfying end to the franchise
The hunger games without the actual hunger games is like tea without water.

It was pretty good!. I enjoyed Peeta alot in this film, any moment between him and katniss is fantastic (i ship them so hard ... and I hardly ever ship characters), I liked the ending, I liked the city of hunger games element ... it was nifty. I disliked the first 30 mins alot, too much poor plot development that just isnt really compelling. Hardly any haymitch, the new characters are bad again, and alot of moments at the end just felt off and shouldn't have fallen into place like they did imo.  

Overall, I liked it ... I wasnt too fond of it on my first viewing, but after a second rewatch I liked it alot more! a mostly satisfying ending (at least for Peeta and Katniss)

Part 2 of Mockingjay brings the action back in full force and concludes the story in a satisfying way. The problem with this film is the pacing, you’d think after splitting the final novel into 2 books that it would help but it still feels rushed. We get some great climatic sequences and some hard hitting emotional surprises, but all feels rushed. The cast continues to carry their characters to new depths and the story unfolds into many twists and turns. The ending feels like it accomplishes what the films set out to do, but without a chance to breathe from the final scenes it’s hard to fully be invested how our characters journeys end.

Previsível e preguiçoso.

O plot é demasiadamente previsível. A subversão da ordem, o atentado para conseguir o poder, a morte da presidente; todos esses elementos poderiam ser mais explorados, mas aqui é tudo tão jogado de maneira descuidada que você nunca é pego de surpresa. No final de contas, nenhum personagem se salva. Suas atitudes são incompreensíveis em suma maioria, e há uma sensação de que o roteiro força acontecimentos para que a historia vá em frente, quando na realidade eles deveriam ser provocados pelas consequências das atitudes dos personagens. O tanto de conveniência e furos aqui é colossal. As cenas de ação parecem mais sem alma do que nunca, como se uma musica de fundo bastasse para que nosso coração acelerasse como o dos personagens.

Enfim, nada mais do que uma decepção.

This movie didn't go down so well when it first released but I on the other hand thoroughly enjoyed it throughout. They didn't change a significant turning point from the books which I appreciate and I was never bored during the teams dangerous traversal in no man's land nor even during the scenes in district 13 at the beginning of the film. An uncommon opinion but I think this was a great send off to the series. I give it 4 stars because it's reflective of my view of this series as a whole, it was a good run but it never quite reached the top tier level along with the "Harry Potter" and "Lord of the Rings" franchises. But a good series none the less.
Special Effects: 1,0/Sound Effects: 0,5/Acting: 1,0/Story: 1,0
The TERRIBLE ending disrespects all elements of the franchise created so far.
Amazing! Awesome conclusion to a phenomenal series.
Spectacular acting, effects, and story. Probably the best in the series.
It was ok, but not nearly as good as the first in this series.

Hunger Games Mockingjay Part 2 was an entertaining movie, with many twists and turns. I was always on the edge of my seating, waiting for what Katniss or President Snow would do. Moves and countermoves, haha. The beginning and middle sections were nicely developed, but the ending was confusing, and a bit rushed. SPOILERS I would have preferred a final battle between the rebel forces and the capitol, instead of the enigma of "what happened?" during the bombing at the capitol's gates.
geting better!!!!!!!!!!

Its potential to be a satisfying conclusion to the franchise is completely wasted with a disrespect to the source material, terrible character and plot decisions, baffling plot twists, dissapointing action and an underwhelming ending, concluding the franchise in the worst way possible.
this is a revolutionary movie about a revelation. it's the best from its action and just everything fight me you fattie💖💖😡

I felt like this movie had no point. She could've stayed home and done nothing and the outcome would've been the same. I'm just saying there was no point in this and that what made the movie terrible. 
Ps the door closing at the end of the movie in the house was weird.

A fine finale to a great young adult series.

Francis Lawrence's teen sci-fi action film The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015) is a massive spectacle featuring insane explosions, large setpieces, impressive CGI, and heartfelt character arcs to conclude Suzanne Collins' YA series: The Hunger Games. Lawrence's direction is solid for the bittersweet end as he makes the action exhilarating, while the Mockingjay's revolutionary losses hurt. He could have done something more experimental as The Hunger Games now feels old hat with so many dystopian coming of age movies around now. Collins' writing is very clever with tyrants and revolutionaries getting critiqued for their brutal methods. I like how Katniss is not the deciding figurehead of the revolution, but merely a symbol of righteousness as The Mockingjay. Her decisive final arrow is a spectacular movie moment, but President Snow's downfall occurs earlier thanks to the people rising up against their oppressive government.

Jennifer Lawrence is wonderful as the heroine Katniss Everdeen. She puts the weight of the world on her capable shoulders with emotive acting and stalwart bravery in the face of danger. Lawrence captures the modern woman who can be both strong and emotional without judgement. I liked her as an actress for all 4 Hunger Games films. 

Furthermore, Josh Hutcherson is great as the brainwashed Peeta Mellark learning to love again. Liam Hemsworth's conflicted feelings are apparent as Gale Hawthorne. Willow Shields is as devastating as Primrose Everdeen as is Mahershala Ali as Boggs. I am sad to see Sam Claflin's Finnick Odair go. I adore the gorgeous Natalie Dormer's courageous camera director Cressida as well as the striking Jena Malone's feisty Johanna Mason.

Donald Sutherland is fantastic as he bows down as the fearsome dictator President Snow. Julianne Moore is amazing as the coldly shrewd President Alma Coin. Philip Seymour Hoffman still gets some memorable moments as revolutionary tactician Plutarch Heavensbee. Woody Harrelson and Elizabeth Banks get emotional send offs as Katniss' mentors Haymitch Abernathy and Effie Trinket. Jeffrey Wright is interesting as the tech wizard Beetee. Stanley Tucci is wasted as the propaganda announcer Caesar Flickerman.

James Newton Howard's score is the unsung hero of The Hunger Games franchise with his emotionally sweeping music. Jo Willems' cinematography comes up with several crafty shots that frame the revolution and the dictators with equal majesty and gravitas. I just wish Suzanne Collins' writing was stuck to more besides her heartfelt look at teenagers building a new world. The zombies underground and the furry fashion designer was just dumb. I think there should have been more action or Katniss shooting her bow to keep you engaged.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 is a bit bloated at 137 minutes, especially when the endings keep coming without satisfaction. I wanted a happier ending I suppose, instead of the bittersweet one with few farewells.
part 2 definitely better then the first part but still didn't enjoy it as much as i hoped for
Didn't satisfy me. For such an emotional series, the conclusion seemed void of it.
Strong final to one of the best teen action film series. The acting is really good and the story comes to a satisfying conclusion.

Is this worth your time?
Yes, I think this movie is worth your time! This movie doesn't exactly live up to the movie of Mockingjay: Part 1. Yes it is all good, but is just ended... well not the way I would have thought it would have. There were scenes I wanted to have in the movie(that the book had) but besides all that, it is a good movie! I give this 83% Rotten Tomatoes!

“Welcome to the 76th Hunger Games...”The final movie in the Hunger Games series, brings forth a conclusion that is satisfying yet also tragic. You will love the send off performances from Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson. Both Stars have given it their all in this movie, and you can really tell that once you see them. This is also the final movie of the great Phillip Seymour Hoffman (RIP)
Beautiful ending to the hunger games saga. Loved all of it!

The movie drags on with melodramatic dialogues that have no genuine leadups. They make the story feel stretched. Amid the blubbering nonsense are thrilling action sequences, that would have been great on their own, but completely throw off the tone of the film. Skip the movie and read the amazing book instead.

The first two movies are really good and the ending to the franchise is kind of weak but after watching it more then once, I can accept that it is a decent ending overall. This teen franchise will be around for along time.

A considerable improvement on Part 1 largely in part to the plot hitting a climax and some scenes which actually carried some intensity and suspense. Not a film to showcase acting talent but just about a good enough end to a good franchise. A dystopian ending never leaves the audience feeling completely satisfied though.
The only reason im doing this is because Finnick died

Mockingjay Part 2 is a very dark and grim conclusion the epic franchise. First of all, I wouldn't recommend this movie for kids who haven't seen this movie for a family-fun movie night. Also, if you haven't seen the franchise and don't like gory stuff and jump scares that will make you jump out of your seat, wait for the DVD. Mockingjay delivers a steady storyline throughout the whole movie. It definitely will make you jump out of your seats for some parts. If you cry at movies you'll cry. Jennifer was top notch through the whole movie. Overall it was a good movie.

This was exactly what I had envisioned when reading the book. A very good ending to the series that we have all loved for so long. The overall story was okay but each character had their own traumas that were so deep and engrossing. Very good!

It's a cinematic masterpiece in every aspect. The fact that the storyline is a critique against capitalism only makes it better, but apart from that: great cast, edition, special effects, plot, soundtrack. Its imposible to not get immersed in the plot every time I watch it and it's just incredible. The The Hunger Games saga evolved gracefully with every new release, and the production in these movies just gets ten times better with each of them. Totally recommend to revisit it (or watch if you haven't already)
It is not a sci fi anymore. Love story of a loving idiot girl. Do not see it! Never ever!
Once this series left the arena and had to think a bit more creatively, it lost steam and direction, and the end result leaves viewers unfulfilled. (2.5/5)

An action-packed and entertaining conclusion, combined with Lawrence's direction, Craig and Strong's script, the performances of the cast, Howard's score, Willems's cinematography, Bell and Yoshikawa's editing, Messina's production design, Dias and Rosinski's set decoration, Kurt and Bart's costume design, action sequences, sound design and visual effects, Part 2 adapts the second half of its source novel faithfully into an entertaining and beautifully filmed final chapter!!!

With an experienced direction by Francis Lawrence, a more than exceptional script by Peter Craig and Danny Strong, an unforgettable soundtrack by James Newton Howard, great action scenes, beautiful visual effects and excellent performances by Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, Liam Hemsworth , Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Banks, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman (rest in peace), Jeffrey Wright, Stanley Tucci, Donald Sutherland and Sam Claflin, The Hunger Games Saga comes to an end with Mockingjay - Part 2, which concludes this series of films in an exciting and memorable way
would be amaizing with Hight Frame rate 120fps
This movie really fails to deliver, the books were so amazing so it was disappointing to see this adaptation to the big picture.
An incredible film! Special effects are fire!

A very good ending to a beloved franchise in both books and films alike. Susan Collins, the creator can't be given enough credit for giving us all of this world. This is a very nice well earned conclusion. Jennifer Lawrence is superb and breathtaking as the powerhouse that is Katniess Everdeen. All the acting was top notch here along with the writing and cinematography and art direction. James Newton Howard crushes it with another poweful final farewell orchestral tune. This is a top 5 franchise of all-time.
About as strong as the first one. It would be perfect if not for the loose ends in the end of the movie. However, the action is very intense, lots of betrayal, and surprising news. Very good movie.
Some moments translate to the screen better than others, but this is still an overall satisfying conclusion to the franchise that doesn't mind stretching things out along the way. (B-)

This movie had the tough task of honouring its books and closing of a series. It had to stick the landing after a disappointing predecessor. It lands, but not as well as maybe it could have.
 
Firstly, to get this out there, it is an well-made movie. It had the thrills and tension you have come to expect from this series, with excellent action set pieces and glorious twists. It's a good movie, with good performances and a satisfactory ending.
 
But it does not quite capture the essence of the franchise. It's gloomy, cold and distant. And what it lacks is the grand finish that Harry Potter did so excellently. It's definitely better than part 1 and the ending we got to was good. But the route to the ending was just too formulaic. A real shame.
Meh it was not that good as the first two but still good
Not the fully rounded finale I wanted but some of the visuals were just too good not to miss. I would recommend it for all who have seen the previous movies in the installment.
Unfortunately thanks to the greedy minds of LionsGate, Mockingjay as whole was an overall disappointing mess that failed to deliver in almost every aspect.
Hunger Games Mockingjay part 2 is pretty good. I know a few people hate this film but in my opinion it is a good film, But it is for sure way better then part 1 of our Mockingjay.

The final film of the saga I was expecting this to be wild and so much happening. I’ll be honest, I was a bit let down by it. I haven’t read the books so I did not know what happened like some people but I just feel the ending was a letdown and it could’ve have been much grander than it was. I still enjoyed it, just not as much as I thought I would.
A good film. But it didn't need to be split in to two parts.
An epic  conclusion to the Hunger Games franchise and Phillip Seymour Hoffman's life and career. R.I.P Phillip... I felt sad that The Hunger Games had to end.

I kinda like these movies, but it's very very very clear that they are written by a woman. I hear men speaking, but with the words of a woman. Is what I would say to quickly sum it up. Concept is good, but it's a bit too much on the romanticized side, and the female aspect of everything that happens always really seeps through. One point I'd like to touch on briefly is the names of the characters. Katniss? Peeta? What the....??? Really? Normal actual people's names exist, you know. Just saying. What's wrong with Catherine, Kate or Pete? Everytime I hear Katniss, I instantly think of catnip.
tooooooo looooong… expected ending, to much sense-less love drama for a "revolution" movie.

Mockingjay Pt 2 improved slightly over the last movie. The action was picked up, thriller was back, characters were in put through the inevitable and were seen in different light than in any other movie, sad deaths were included, and the conclusion was satisfying after the gruel and dark events that led up to this happy ending. What sucked was that it was split, dragged the first half, and the hype was a bit too much. Good franchise though! I will forever love The Hunger Games.
Return of the Jedi it ain't.

What a waste of a series. To much cloak and dagger, politics not enough action. It would been better if they storm the capital with her leading the troops and the ending was stupid. This movie lost my interest almost at the beginning, I was hoping it would get better but it didn’t. I so glad I didn’t waste my money on this movie. This series should be redone with more action and less politics and cloak and dagger.
Its good. They didn't blow it, which i was afraid they might do. But their are some flaws that make certain things convent and kinda un earned.
This series of films was terrible. Glad it's done.
Part 2 of the 3rd movie is the same as part 1 except the ending takes a turn.
The books really are a movie script.

Which is the goal? What happens to characters after the end? To critique a story, not only we must see the words written, but also those meant, what happens between the scenes, or after the end. We a dystopia, criticizing modern issues of course, and not the future, as any dystopia or eutopia (and not utopia). And we see a hero! As always. What about the rest of people living there? And how more sexist can it get (meant spoiler), the ending? The hero —and a few more characters— can do a big success , like a revolution. But what about the rest? We can't all be big success, otherwise no one would be. This is a competitive view on society, and most stories are based on this, as well as a "villain" who makes the protagonist "the good guy" for no apparent reason: they good guys don't seem to make any big choices: they were just born in this world and (violently) fight for their lives. It also glorifies violence to some extent. And how can a story (action or not) be without all these? It can, and I have read it. This book ("Political thinking for the masses: way to freedom", Tsikoudis) talks about life, how we can be without all these (hatred, violence, demonization, sexism).

Way better than the first half of mockingjay, it is a little long and drags at times but for the most part it is a fitting and satisfying end to the hunger games saga. As always in this series, the dialogue flails at times but there are a few genuine moments of tension throughout, as well as a whole lot of ending. Pretty much every major character gets a farewell scene and I like that there was an unexpected twist or two before it all wraps up. It's dark and deals with several complex ideas about government and propaganda as the series as a whole always tried to do. The award winning actors do their best with the material and it all comes together nicely enough.
An improvement over part 1, part 2 focuses more on action scenes over character drama. Even so, it's still a very entertaining finale that ends with plenty of philosophical conviction
Not what I expected, but was still a good movie
Good action sequences but the story stretches in parts without explanation. Deaths of seemingly important characters just glossed over and left untold.
Despite being so faithful to its source material (which brings the storytelling flaws to the big screen), Part 2 delivers and entertains.
It's a great ending to a great story.
Fin de una de las mejores sagas de esta decada.
"The Hunger Games; Mockingjay part 2" is a great conclusion to "The Hunger Games" films.

The first film was great, the second just about stayed at a decent level, the third struggled...so no suprise that this is turgid dross.  It's sooo boring, and sooo long.  Lots of this film is just people wondering around what look like bombed out shopping centres arguing.  If you're surprised by the arrow shot you're an idiot, this is drivel, and long drivel at that.
Underwhelming.  I expected more.
Not as good as in the novel
A great finale to the Hunger Games series, Mockingjay: Part 2 is full of the action and emotion that easily satisfies the fans of this saga.
The end I love to bits but that's was it. The rest was average, no were near the first Mockingjay. Disappointing finish to the series
Very Weak after Part 1. I kept waiting for something to happen, but not Much did

The Hunger Games movies have drawn a very mixed reaction from me. I thought that first one was just ok, the second one to be good, and Mocking Jay part 1 to be decent. Mocking Jay part 2 feels pretty bland to me. Nothing stood out as a defining quality for this movie. The ending just feels poorly put together and underwhelming.
I don't know about this one, there is not that much to say. It's a little silly finale to the franshise and I think both Mockingjay movies suffer because they divided it into 2 parts.

Mockingjay es uno de las maneras erróneas de finalizar una franquisia aceptable que ponia la dureza de su historia y personajes por encima de los sentimientos de los mismo, y que alfinal busca dar su toque profundo y sentimental con cliches aburridos que realmente decepciona de grandes maneras.
Mockingjay Part 2 is depressing and violent, filled with action-packed sequences.

CONSISTENTLY good and dealing with complex themes the film seldom puts a foot wrong. The absence of humor and lighter moments REINFORCES a feeling for me that greater attention  could have to "Entertainment" value to the benefit of all concerned.

Mockingjay Part 2 is impressively more gripping and dark than Part 1. Instead of staging its heroine and her entourage in front of the battle, they are trudging a couple of hours behind the battle lines to film more propaganda for the rebel’s. A decision that was decided on Katniss’ behalf. Instead of giving us an explosive finale, it’s more like entire a bottomless pit, the story takes many turns and it’s grim all around, save for an ounce of hope towards the end of the film. I respect the decision because the book was like that. Jennifer Lawrence gives a subtle but emotionally complex performance as Katniss Everdeen. If it’s predecessors were about being angry, she pulls it off. In this final installment, her anger had simmered down, in its place is a more weary Katniss, a young woman thrown into the ringer too many times. It’s compelling and devastating to watch.
It’s a good conclusion with good action. But it’s just good and nothing else

This is not an action movie, but it has a lot of action scenes of the final struggle between the rebellion and president Snow. It also has many drama scenes which explore the evolution of the characters and political developments in Panem. Fans of action movies might be irritated by the amount of drama scenes. The movie is an atypical anti-war drama since it plays inside a revolution and avoids most of the typical battle scenes of other (anti-)war movies but instead depicts violence in unusual ways. When violence appears on screen, it sometimes is gruesome, bordering on horrific. The story explores several highly significant topics of warfare, which are ignored by other war movies. The movie has an original score with truly remarkable tracks, some romantic, some wildly energetic, others iconic for the franchise.
The pacing had some problems. some scenes were stretched out without necessity, e.g. at the begin of the team operation in the Capitol. On the other side, the climax of the war needed a little more time, a steady cam and a zoom into the scene.

The acting in the last part of the franchise was again very good. Donald Sutherland shines again as diabolic, cold blooded tyrant in his final fight against his arch enemy Katniss Everdeen and her friends. Jenna Malone and Sam Claflin are very convincing. Josh Hutcherson shows an astounding variety and intensity of his character. Jennifer Lawrence portrays the evolving personality of Katniss Everdeen with precision, lots of detail and calm power.

The story of the revolution comes to an end. This movie is thematically extremely dark. The revolution war creates hell on earth. The characters undergo transformation under the immense pressure of what happens around them. War brings out the best and the worst in humans. Everybody has a choice: be shattered into pieces by the violence or be consumed by hate or grow to a personal strength that allows to love and protect fellow men?
"He who fights with monsters might take care lest he thereby become a monster. And when you gaze long into an abyss the abyss also gazes into you." - Friedrich Nietzsche.

SPOILERS AHEAD:

Snow delivered a massive precision strike against Katniss at the end of part 1. That threw Katniss and Peeta into a very personal hell where her soul and Peeta's are suffering agony. Her strongest personality trait which has always been her saving grace since her father died is the one which keeps her alive and going. With sheer willpower Katniss stands up and determines herself on getting revenge for Peeta.  Katniss is not crying anymore for peeta in this movie. She shed so many tears in part 1, now she is emotionally exhausted. But Katniss still has her morality, charisma, willpower and wits.

While Peeta undergoes a very slow mental healing in hospital, Coin uses Katniss as a propaganda tool for her rebel army on the path to Snow. During the fights, Katniss gets into life threatening situations where firepower cannot save her but only her personality can. She is appalled by the cruelness and perfidiousness of some allies and she has to reconsider whom she can trust. She feels more alone than ever.
In the beginning of the movie, her revenge for Peeta is all that matters to her, but after she witnesses the love other people show to each other, she undergoes another personality transformation. Katniss declares that Snow corrupts everybody and everything. She realizes that Snow is a threat to all good and the love inside humans. She commits herself to kill Snow, so that love can continue to exist, even if this costs her own life.
Katniss grows beyond her borders again and emancipates herself from the rebellion. She has more important things to do than posing for propaganda videos or fight for Coin's power. Katniss decides she has to liberate humanity from Snow's corrupting influence, from surveillance cameras, propaganda and deadly games.

But on her path towards fulfilling her self selected destiny, Katniss runs into an obstacle. She is forced to join Coin's propaganda team to create more videos for Coin. During her march towards Snow, she has to convince the team on her mission, she has to survive Snow's deadly traps and cope with a reappearance of Peeta, who is still somewhat brainwashed and a lethal danger to Katniss. Katniss realizes she cannot let go of Peeta and tries to heal him with the power of her love. As they fight through the Capitol, her team has to save each other's lives many times. Nonetheless, her comrades die left and right beside her. Katniss realizes she made a horrible mistake, she also underestimated Snow's power and Snow lands a devastating strike. Katniss cannot stand the pain anymore. She Is in her darkest hour, but she is not alone. Her friends put her onto her feet and Katniss finds her resolve to march forward as long as she lives. But the worst has yet to come. Katniss has to endure a boundless amount of pain which threatens to destroy both her body and her mind. 

Katniss receives a revelation from an unexpected source. She has to make one final decision that changes the life of everyone in Panem forever. To fulfill her destiny, Katniss depends on her ability to grow beyond her borders, rely on her own morality and on the trust of her friends.

The movie shows the immediate and long term effects of Katniss' decisions during the revolution.

Watch the movie until the end of credits. The music is sensational. The best film score I ever heard.

INTERPRETATION of the entire franchise:

After having read several analyses of book readers and movie watchers, I want to present the most fascinating one of them:
The story of Katniss is the search of a soul for union with god.
In the entire franchise there is no mention or sign of any religion, instead a tyrant enslaves humanity with violence (in the districts) and hedonism (in the Capitol). This tyrant subdues morality, awareness, compassion and conscience in humans. He corrupts everybody and everything, he turns humans and animals into murderers and Monsters (mutts). He is the personification of Satan who reigns on earth.

In her innocent childhood, Katniss was in union with god, personificated by her father. The books describe her unconditional love and closeness towards him. In this state, Katniss represented Adam, the ancestor of humanity being in Eden.  After she lost her father, Katniss and her mother fell out of Eden into the harsh world and had to live in world without god. Her mother represents Eve who enters a catatonic state of despair from the loss of union with god in Eden. Now Katniss' personality is a hybrid of masculinity and femininity, she is hunting, feeding and comforting as father and mother to her Family, representing all of humankind.

In the 74th hunger games, Katniss meets Rue, which symbolizes a plant which can heal the eyes. Katniss begins to see Rue as another sister. Witnessing Rue's violent death enables Katniss to express powerful love and compassion for other people and to see the requirement for all people to love other people as brothers and sisters. This is the begin of the end of Satan's reign on earth as her behaviour is televised to everbody and inspires them to follow her example.

Peeta saved Katniss' life when he nourished her with bread. He saves her again from the career tributes. He inspires Katniss to tears with his realistic painting of Rue's grave. He has been in love with Katniss (humankind) since he saw her the first time and he publicly declares his love for Katniss. At the end of the 74th games, Peeta wants to sacrifice his life so that Katniss will be redeemed from the deadly games. Haymitch tells Katniss she would not deserve Peeta in 100 lifetimes. Peeta represents Jesus Christ who unconditionally loves, protects and inspires the humankind he is willing to die for.

Before the 75th games, Peeta declares publicly: "the bond of love is our greatest prize. For it is true love that allows us all to bear our hardships, that mends the heart and banishes loneliness and gives meaning to our lifes." This is Jesus Christ explaining to humankind that love is the essence of divinity. Katniss (representing humankind) has to find love for Peeta for her soul to find redemption and union with god. In a conversation in the train, Peeta encourages her to open her soul to accept a bond with him. During the victory tour, Katniss' soul is in pain and fear and when she asks Peeta to stay with her during night, Peeta comforts Katniss and pledges eternal support. They spend each night together in bed, but there is no sexuality. Katniss will never again be alone with her fear in the darkness, Katniss and Peeta have made an eternal bond between Jesus Christ and humankind, so that humans bonded with Christ do not have to fear death anymore.

During the 75th games, when Peeta nearly dies, Katniss realizes the strength of her love for Peeta, she panics at the prospect of losing him. The importance of the eternal bond between Christ and humankind is fully realized in Katniss and that bond must never be broken. Peeta donates a pearl to Katniss as a token and pledge of the eternal love of Christ to humankind. Katniss holds this pearl close and safe for the rest of her life. It will remind her of Peeta's love when she cannot see him.

Katniss commits to sacrificing her life to destroy the game arena of Snow (Satan), thereby breaking the power of Satan on earth. Her body nearly dies, she passes out, her arms are spread out, light from above shines onto her while she is being lifted into the sky. Katniss has become a martyr. But her task on earth is not finished yet, so she wakes up and comes back to earth. Katniss endures a figurative death and rebirth as the Mockingjay because she has followed the example of Jesus Christ's sacrifice to redeem humankind from evil. Katniss herself now has become a mythic being: the Mockingjay with symbolic wings and a powerful weapon is a synonym of archangel Michael, who will defeat Satan at the end of days. As archangel Michael, patron of soldiers, Katniss inspires then also leads the army of the part of humankind which is in divine grace against the army of Satan. Katniss is revered everywhere she goes and many people sacrifice their life for her idea of fighting Satan. While Peeta (Christ) is captured by Snow (Satan), Katniss becomes Christ's deputy on earth, she becomes the face, voice and later also the deadly force of the revolution against Snow,

Her love in Peeta gets severely tested when Peeta comes back from Snow's capture as a programmed assassin to kill her. Snow (Satan) has taken possession of the body of Peeta. But Katniss knows that this assassin is not Peeta. She made an eternal bond with him before the 75th games and after being supported by Haymitch, she uses the power of love to restore Peeta's mind in his original shape, thereby performing exorcism on Peeta.
When Katniss seems to have lost her confidence in doing the right thing because of all the suffering she induces and witnesses in the war, Peeta reminds her of her task. She (as archangel Michael) is meant to defeat Snow (Satan). There is no turning back for her and her army.

Before the end, Katniss also has to recognize and defeat a false prophet who wants to usurp Satan's reign on earth with perfidious heinousness.
After Satan and his reign got annihilated, in the end, Katniss unites with Peeta for eternity and gives birth to children. Humankind is redeemed from evil and in its eternal bond of love with Christ, the soul of Katniss and humankind becomes immortal, with their children being their physical representation of immortality and the meadow the representaion of paradise, the place where humankind and god are united.

Awful, a disappointment to the series, I hate it and you all should never watch this. The movie so.mehow manages to mock itself.
 This is a DISGRACE!!!
the perfect ending to a perfect series. here's hoping to seeing jlaw and josh hutch in more films in the near future. their chemistry is unmatched.
Mildly better than its first part, but still relies on the protagonist whining her way into storylines.

A satisfying and exciting end to a great film series, it does drag a little bit but I can't complain I wasn't satisfied by the end. the acting is still strong and the characters were well cast. Fantastic cinematography as well. 04-08-2018
A terrific ending, to a very thought provoking series.
with the first part of the mockingjay i stated my opinion as 'enough' however i felt the need to watch this one too and well i don't regret because I like closures but still; enough.
Still Not As Good As The First Two But A Bit Better Than Mockingjay Part 1!!!!

It's a decent movie with and interesting story, in a dark world. But most of the time it was predictable, except for one or two twists, that where welcomed. It was very slow paced at first, and nothing interesting happened until the first 30 minutes, but after that it picks up, and even gives a satisfying ending to the saga, although it was a little bit cliche it's still bearable. Very well acted directed and every other element of the movie was awesome. Overall it's a pretty good movie with an above average rating. (Watchable)

Disclaimer, I am unsure whether or not I've seen Part 1 of the Hunger Games Mocking Jay. I'm like 90% sure I have but there at least a 20% chance I haven't.* Nevertheless, I watched the Hunger Games Mocking Jay Part 2 last night and was incredibly underwhelmed. I feel like absolutely nothing happened. For starters, I was super confused by the first few minutes of the movie because either a considerable amount of time has passed since the last movie left off, or again, I didn't see the last movie so it would make sense that parts are missing for me. But that's not why I didn't like the movie, I didn't like it because the storyline just sucked and they tried to hide that with cool weapons and big explosions and that's not enough to win me over! (throw in a couple cheesy jokes though and I'm all in) This movie was so predictable too, every death you could see from a mile away and knew when characters weren't actually in any real danger. At no point was I captivated by this movie. Then the ending came and I think any 5-year-old daughter could have predicted this. This movie came out like 3 years ago so I'm spoiling it. So Katniss is walking up the 2-mile long walkway, which she finishes in 30 seconds and is getting ready to shoot Snow, the evil president. But standing straight behind him on a raised platform is the new soon to be evil president who they didn't realize was evil until now. So what does Katniss do? She raises her bow just slightly and nails her right in the heart. Oh my gosh, who saw that one coming!?!? Literally everyone.

"Mockingjay Part 1" was an extremely boring movie that just set-up the big finale of "Mockingjay Part 2", and it's boring again. The only redeeming factors for this movie is that Jennifer Lawrence is once again great as Katniss, and the fact that something occasionally happened. The big twist at the end is extremely disappointing and the ending really stretches on to long.

I enjoyed the Hunger Games movies overall, but I felt they progressively got a little less interesting with each instalment. I don't know if I tired of it or the novelty/freshness of it wore off for me. 1 & 2 were by far the best films, with 3 & 4, the Mocking Jay additions being more of a confused mish mash of action & drawing out of the love triangle which was never really much of a triangle bc things were always going to go the way they did.
The perfect way to end the saga and an excellent adaptation of the book. Mockingjay Part 2 is entertaining and exciting.

Whilst the depressing and dark tone, Mockingjay Part 2 ends the acclaimd franchise with solid performances, relentless action sequences and a poignant conclusion. Jennifer Lawrence and the rest of the talented cast ends The Hunger Games overall to a successful note.

Puntaje Original: 6.5

Mi opinión es la misma que la parte 1, así que concluyo que mas que pensar en el aspecto comercial, deben pensar en hacer una película de calidad, estoy convencido de que si hubieran hecho una sola película de Sinsajo, hubiera sido más intensa y emocionante, y una trilogía hecha a la medida de los libros.
The bottom line is that I was at the edge of my seat the entire time! Amazing and climatic to its full potential, with cliffhangers and jumpscares, the Hunger Games Mockingjay Part 2 is beautiful!

I have a lot of problems with this movie, particularly the ending.  First, I wasn't clear whether Gale constructed the bomb that killed Prim or whether he was the one who came up with the idea of the bombing.  If it is the former, then it is ridiculous to blame him for Prim's death.  Bombs are created to kill people in war, and he had no idea or way of knowing it would kill someone on his side, much less Katniss's own sister, who he swore to protect.  If that is the story line, then I lost all respect for Katniss for sending him away for that reason after all he did for her and sacrificed to protect her family.  It would have been much more tolerable if she just told him the truth that she didn't love him the way she loves Peeta and that Peeta represents hope and all that is good in life, whereas Gale is a rebel and a reminder of bad memories of war and the death of her sister.  I think she made the right choice because she is a better match with Peeta, but she showed a complete lack of gratitude to Gale for all that he had been through for her.  She could have at least had the courage to tell him the truth about her feelings rather than using the excuse of a bomb that he may or may not have built.  If, on the other hand, the latter is true (that Gale came up with the idea of the bombing in the first place), then I find that completely out of line with his character.  He previously said that he could live with a few civilian casualties if it was for the greater good of destroying the capitol.  I can't imagine that he would have ever condoned dropping a bomb deliberately on the refugees, including children, as they walked into the capitol, especially after how we have seen him as a protector of Katniss's family.  He would have supported attacking President Snow, and could have lived with some civiilian casualties, but to say that he would concoct an idea to drop bombs on refugees is just totally out of line with who we got to know in the previous movies.  Secondly, I thought it was a terrible way to end the movie by having Katniss kill President Coin.  If she killed Coin  out of fear of her getting too much power, then why didn't she instead vote no on the Hunger Games when she was given the opportunity and then proceed to try to overthrow Coin by legal means rather than by killing? Katniss, who often seems reluctant to kill people of the opposing side because she sees the good in them, determines that killing Coin is the only way to remedy a bad situation? Could she not have stood up to her and organized the people to do a fair election? I like to think she could have at least tried and probably been successful since she has the support and respect of the rebels.  Killing Coin was a cowardly and cheap way out, something she didn't have the courage to do to President Snow, who caused her much more harm.  And, if she killed her simply to get revenge for Prim, then what kind of leader is she? Is that what the heroine of the story represents - revenge and anger? What she did was premeditated murder because she voted yes on the Hunger Games with a plan in mind all along that she was going to kill Coin rather than Snow.  It's so ironic that she was fighting to liberate the people from Snow and yet instead of using the newfound freedom to rise up and select a new leader of their, own she resorted to violence.  I find this to be the most disappointing from a character that I thought more of.
Excelente final, el mejor para la saga. Es una cinta seria y cruda, muestra lo que una guerra puede hacer.
While the ending is terrible like in the book. Solid performances and great action sequences redeem the film.

This is a slow and tedious movie, way too long and really boring. The only positives are the performances by the already established cast and few of the hunger games style fights sequences on offer, the special effects are sadistically cool. Did enjoy the execution in the end but they had to spoil that too by extending the ending in concluding the love story. Bad end to a mediocre four movie series.

This was a very disappointing ending to the series. The action was entertaining and the performances were good but everything else fell flat. For a lot of this movie I was bored and was not satisfied with the ending. 

5.7/10

Woah, what an ending! I did not see any flaw in the film. Well done at all levels. Only low are the mutts that seems a bit too willing to die to kill. No animal does that. But they could be under some influence I guess. I liked the style, the story line not too predictable, the ending even if I guessed the shocker, or maybe more because they allowed us to guess it. And the very bucolic epilogue. I am impressed that a young author could have thought of all this, although I haven't read the books. There is an ending that is not a low point!

"The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2" defiantly finishes the franchise with a bang, no not a bang something even more than that. "Mockingjay Part 2" defiantly gives the fans a more than satisfying conclusion. The plot begins at the same point "Mockingjay Part 1" left off. For all past deaths made as entertainment, and for the insidious modification of Peeta, Katniss deems to strike out on her own to take down President Snow once and for all, but being the Mockingjay, the living symbol of the rebellion now headed by Alma Coin, has its drawbacks. Recognition, for one, and she finds herself saddled with a team of expert warriors (which surprisingly includes the ailing Peeta) aimed to penetrate the Capitol that has barricaded itself behind Hunger-Game-style death traps. As she closes in on carrying out her private agenda through more deaths and mayhem, President Snow himself makes her aware of another threat to peace for Panem equal to himself, leaving her to consider how to truly end the bloodshed. 

Once again the director "Francis Lawrence" is very smooth with his style and truly is the perfect director for these films. He again brings very beautiful visuals to the screen with the locations and brings back the "games" in a perfect way. "Jennifer Lawrence" was exceptional as always but in this one she defiantly boosts her performance as a character with PTSD. I can proudly say that this is the best she preformed in the franchise and even up to "Silver Linings" and "Joy" standards. "Josh Hutcherson" is very good in this film as well. Although this is his toughest part in the role yet is defiantly not his best as I liked him a lot better in Mockingjay Part 1. "Sam Claflin" also boosts his game as Finnick Odair and with a lot more screen time then he had in "Mockingjay Part 1". This film has major character development and its amazing to watch on screen. To see where Katniss began at the beginning of the movie to the end blows your mind. But unfortunately the Secondary characters do not have as big character development they still do have some. 

You can tell they spent every single penny they had wisely on this film. With an extremely high budget of an estimated $160 Million the special effects are exceptional. The underground lizard mutts where very very well done in terms of CGI as well as the multiple explosions and the avenue of the tributes in snows execution scene. The Original Motion Score composed by James Newton Howard was one of the best in the Franchise. With the multiple standouts being, your favourite colour is green, Sewer Attack, Rebels Attack, Snows Execution and the Medley. Once again the Pace in this film is perfect. The aim when Squad 451 got into the capitol was to make it feel like a ghost town and the pace at that point made it feel so much more like the ghost town they where going for. Then it starts to speed up with the majority of the action scenes in the middle at its climax. 

Overall "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2" is a more than satisfying ending to the franchise as it goes out with a bang. With exceptional acting, characters, special effects and a perfect score and almost no flaws apart from small pacing issues near the middle of the film. I give 2015's "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2" a 10/10.
the movie is bad, really bad. The dialog is worse than need for speed and many of the cosepts dosent give any sense. Its still a good "action" though
Controversial opinion... This is my favorite Hunger Games movie.
Perhaps a little slow and less epic than it could have been, The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part - 2 nevertheless brings its franchise to a suitably tense and certainly definitive ending.
Horrible. If i'm paying money to watch a good movie, it's not to watch Jennefer Lawrance cry and pose in green screen IN THE ACTUAL MOVIE FILMED ON GREEN SCREEN. Unbelievable money grabbing crap.

An improvement on part one. It's grim, while also giving proper closure to the series. Still, this could've been something special if they had made it into one two and a half hour movie instead of over stretching it to more than four hours.

The final book shouldn't have been divided into two films. A good edit could've made one good stand alone film. Instead, we have a franchise dragging its feet to a meh conclusion. There are some decent action sequences in between a painfully slow and watered down story.

This movie is like a 70's bush: in need of serious trimming. Its biggest failure is in its strict adherence to every damn thing that is in the book, when a lot of it does not translate to film and was stupid in the first place. This story would have been so much better served by just making one long movie instead of overstuffing two with extraneous characters and crap that does not drive the plot forward. Consequently, this chapter lacks focus. On top of that, the ending (or rather, endings) is just terrible, the film tries to tie up all the loose ends in about 10 minutes. It feels very rushed, which is insane for a 2.5 hour movie with one hour of real content. Then there is the sugary "Harry Potter-esque" dénouement that's just odd after a movie that's so pervasively dismal. The middle hour is fun and exciting, even though you usually can't figure out who is who or what is happening due to the quick cuts, the dim lighting, and the fact that the characters are dressed the same. But at least it keeps you interested. The director did not do such a good job with the emotional side of the film either, it's super grim and totally humorless, and there is only one truly emotional scene... and it's between JLaw and a cat. Similar to the last film, this one does a good job of exploring politics and the power of media, and had some interesting things to say about the cycle of oppression, so it does have some merit. But mostly, I was just not impressed. It's disappointing, there is a good story hiding in here, but the filmmakers did not capitalize on the opportunities to improve on the book's many weaknesses. For the most part, The Hunger Games has been a quality film franchise, it deserved a better send-off than this.

Y esta historia llegó a su fin. MUY fiel al texto original. Las escenas de acción fueron muy intensas aunque tuvo sus momentos bajos. Esperaba sentir más dolor por... ellos. Música instrumental maravillosa y apropiada. Efectos, maquillaje y vestuario geniales. Tuvo un final lento pero fiel. Para mí, fue ÉPICO.
It's satisfying as it can get, but could have hit harder, or came off memorable.
Really good, better than part one.
2nd best out of all the films and brings franchises best and most emotional action scenes. Best of 2015!

The decision to drag out the last book into a 2-part movie was a bad one. Every scene seems too long then it should without carrying any emotional weight for the characters. I had issues with some unclear plot lines with the book, and it seems to have translated over to the movie as well.

A grim, realistic ending to the series that gave exactly what fans wanted. This installment moves quicker than its predecessor and successfully balances action with character development. Great end to the series!
The more I watch this movie the more the novelty of it wears off.  I do think that Jennifer Lawrence was born to play Katniss, I just feel like these last two movies were missing something.
That was a freaking awesome ending!

Having watched all four movies back to back like how one might binge on a mini series, this is a review of the entire series as a whole. 
The first Hunger Games was OK- it was pretty much an expensive version of Fukasaku's Battle Royale (from the year 2000 if I recall correctly). In hindsight it felt like a dress rehearsal for the second instalment. 
Catching Fire was a major improvement, with the socio-political elements of the Panem societies explored, and with real suspense and tension in the second half of the film.
Mocking Jay part 1 felt like a couple of 2004 battle star galactica episodes, with a lot of back and forth in political maneuvering through info and propaganda battles. It is an escalation on the world building beyond the televised battle to the death arena.
Mockingjay part 2, was a nice wrap up to the entire series, showing how societies are never as black and white as oppressors and oppressed, good guys and bad guys. In a power struggle of politics and war, nobody really wins.

I really enjoyed this part. Like I said in my "Mockingjay Part 1" review it seemed this entire book was written to please the fans/didn't know how to end the series/get the biggest react. However part 2 was done extremely well and actually caught my attention unlike part 1. 
Which I fell asleep watching, making me have to re-watch it.
